description: From Latin dehortārī, present active infinitive of dēhortor (“to deter, dissuade”), from dē- (“prefix indicating reversal or undoing”) + hortor (“to encourage, exhort, urge”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰer- (“to yearn for”)).

verbs.description: dehort (third-person singular simple present dehorts, present participle dehorting, simple past and past participle dehorted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare or obsolete) To dissuade. [from mid 16th c.]
